author: potuz
content: <@!311971895828283393> perhaps add to the prysm PR that bazel 3.7.0 is required, still couldn't manage to make it work with 4.0.0, and even with 3.7.0 depending on the system you still need to fix WORKSPACE because of the llvm

author: protolambda
content: Same here, bazel trouble is real. The issue for llvm was re-opened. Downgrading to llvm 9 works for the linux users. Bazel has a fix for it apparently, but only in bazel 4. I used bazelisk (the go version) to run bazel.

author: protolambda
content: For Prysm, there's a patch of the beacon-block ssz code (ethereumapis repo) being tested, to be compatible with the other eth2 clients for merge interop.

author: potuz
content: I'm ussing llvm 11 instead of downgrading to 9, but still can' t recognize the system one

author: potuz
content: and since this is what I'm using for my personal node on mainnet I vouch for this üôÇ

author: protolambda
content: it's not trying to use the system one anyway

author: potuz
content: yeah, it does try to look for it but it fails

author: protolambda
content: it's downloading the llvm toolchain straight from github releases

author: potuz
content: I tried tinkering with it but couldn' t make it find it

author: protolambda
content: and fails on various linux distributions, because of spotty releases

author: protolambda
content: Downgrading to 9 worked for me. (and yes, not happy about it)

author: potuz
content:
to use whatever version you want (but still download it) you can change like this WORKSPACE:
```
 llvm_toolchain(
     name = "llvm_toolchain",
-    llvm_version = "10.0.0",
+    llvm_version = "11.0.0",
+    distribution = "clang+llvm-11.0.0-x86_64-linux-gnu-ubuntu-20.04.tar.xz",
 )
```

author: protolambda
content: nice, will try that later

author: suburbandad_
content: Looking good to participate in Friday's test net

author: protolambda
content: Awesome

author: protolambda
content: I think testnet config is ready in ~2 hours from now

author: timbeiko
content: Love the name!

author: protolambda
content: We (ef devops) will run the majority of this testnet on teku-geth, which has had the most testing so far. But then also some lighthouse, nethermind, and maybe prysm. I'll distribute 512 validator keys to each dev team (assuming there are 8 teams that can run 1 or 2 proposing nodes for debugging purposes).

author: protolambda
content: The testnet will be called "Steklo". Glass material in Russian, named after the rayonism painting linked above. Shapes are vaguely recognizable, and it's fragile, but of great use.

author: protolambda
content: Genesis likely 12 UTC Friday

author: protolambda
content: Can move it later/forward still, feedback welcome.

author: protolambda
content: The intention is that we start and ensure connections between nodes on Thu though, so genesis time shouldn't matter too much. Especially not for a 1-day testnet

author: protolambda
content: And we can call the 2nd longer testnet next week after the rayonism-cats painting; glass is broken by the cats üòπ

author: suburbandad_
content: how will the key distribution happen?

author: protolambda
content: One thing I'm not sure about yet is how much time we put between the eth1 genesis time and eth2 genesis time. Technically they can be equal in the configs, with an eth2-genesis delay of 0. But that's bound to break

author: protolambda
content: I'll just send a pre-loaded mnemonic to each team, and with https://github.com/protolambda/eth2-val-tools (for devs, not for mainnet) you can get the keystores of the first 512 accounts in your mnemonic, in all the formats, to put straight into any eth2 validator client.

author: protolambda
content: The genesis state will then contain validator entries for all those accounts of all those mnemonic tranches

author: ajsutton
content: <@!524738020033691659> I can help you with getting keys setup from the mnemonics if needed. We've gone through the same process a number of time for various testnets.

author: protolambda
content: Happy to help any dev team with running a validator client too. Doing some live test block proposals yourself should be fun.

author: protolambda
content: At 512/16384 keys, each dev team gets 1 block proposal every epoch (32 slots) on average. And we try to maintain finality with 12288 keys (think I'll split between 12 nodes, 1024 each, 10 teku, 2 lighthouse, and some eth1 mix). As testnets make progress in stability, we'll do less and less, until every team runs an equal amount + lots of regular users. Maybe we'll even switch some over during the Steklo if things go better than expected. But interop first, then stability, then balance.
